'Niue' ( ; Niuean: NiuÄ) is an island country in the South Pacific Ocean,
northeast of New Zealand and within the triangle formed by Tonga (to the
southwest), the Samoas (to the northwest) and the Cook Islands (to the
southeast). Its land area is and its population, predominantly Polynesian, is
around 1,400. They commonly refer to the island as "the Rock", a reference to
the traditional moniker "Rock of Polynesia".

Niue is a self-governing state in free association with New Zealand, and most of
its diplomatic relations are conducted by New Zealand on Niue's behalf.
According to Tony Angelo, professor of international law at Victoria University
of Wellington, in practice this means that Niue develops its foreign relations
freely, with assistance from New Zealand when it is required and assented to by
Niue. http://www.upf.pf/IMG/pdf/12-RJP15-Pacific-Constitutions.pdf
(page 162) http://www.upf.pf/IMG/pdf/Angelo_RJP_HS04_2004-31.pdf
(page 333). All Niueans are New Zealand citizens, and Queen Elizabeth II is
Niue's head of state in her capacity as Queen of New Zealand. 90â95% of Niuean
people live in New Zealand, along with about 70% of the speakers of
the Niuean language. Moseley, Christopher and R. E. Asher, ed. Atlas of the
World's Languages (New York: Routelage, 1994) p. 100

Even though Niue is not a member of the United Nations, its status as a freely-
associated state has been accepted by UN organs as equivalent to independence
for international law purposes. http://www.justice.govt.nz/publications/publications-
archived/2000/pacific-peoples-constitution-report-september-
2000/documents/Bibliography.doc (see page 41). Both Niue and the Cook
Islands are members in their own right of UN Specialized Agencies such as UNESCO, [http://www.unesco.org/new/en/member-
states/countries/ Countries | United Nations Educational, Scientific and
Cultural Organization]. Unesco.org. Retrieved on 2013-08-09. FAO, [http://www.fao.org/legal/home/fao-
members/en/ Legal Office: FAO Members]. Fao.org. Retrieved on 2013-08-09.
UNCLOS, [http://www.un.org/Depts/los/reference_files/chronological_lists_of-
_ratifications.htm Chronological lists of ratifications of]. Un.org. Retrieved
on 2013-08-09. and UNFCCC, [http://unfccc.int/parties_and_observers/p-
arties/non_annex_i/items/2833.php List of Non-Annex I Parties to the
Convention]. Unfccc.int (2013-01-14). Retrieved on 2013-08-09. among other
specialised agencies and international organizations.

In 2003, Niue became the world's first "Wi-Fi nation", in which free wireless
Internet access is provided throughout the country by The Internet Users Society-
Niue.
categories: Freely associated states of New Zealand
